Description: Hollow terracotta figure of Harpokrates standing on a rounded plinth with mouldings, wearing a short-sleeved long tunic and holding his pot in his left arm, the right hand placed inside its mouth. He has feminine breasts and his phallus emerges from below his garment and rests on the plinth. But for his side-lock he is shaven, and has lotus buds on top of his head, held by a knotted ribbon. Back unmodelled; circular vent in a slight depression. Two-piece mould. Very micaceous brown Nile silt; traces of an overall white dressing.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Ptolemaic or Roman, first century BC/AD. Comparanda: Very close, probably same mould-series: Allen 1985: nos 56 and 57, from Karanis, dated second half of third century AD = Frankfurter 1998: pl. 9; Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1889.1224, thought to be from Hawara; Bayer-Niemeier 1988: nos 102 and 103, dated late first century AD; Besques 1992: no. E 374, perhaps from Antinoopolis, dated beginning of the Roman period (= Ballet 1997: 255, fig. 8 and Ballet 1998: 221, fig. 4); Breccia 1934: no. 72 (two others illustrated on pl. xxiii, two more on pl. xxiv); Christie’s 'Sale Catalogue', 13 July 1983: lot 330; Dunand 1990: nos 130 and 131, dated Roman period, and no. 308 (base fragment); Ewigleben and von Grumbkow 1991: no. 13; Fischer 1994: no. 606, dated first century AD; Fjeldhagen 1995: no. 9, dated late first century AD; Hilton Price 1897: 392, no. 3255, from the Fayum; 'LIMC' iv (2): pl. 247, Harpokrates 142b; Paul 1959: no. 303, dated late Hellenistic; Petrie 1911: pl. xv:18, from a surface chamber in a cemetery north-east of Hawara pyramid; Van Wijngaarden 1958: no. 20; Weber 1914: nos 109–12, 109 said to be from the Fayum, 112 from Ptolemais Euergetis. Bibliog: Budge 1925: pl. xxviii.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3052)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
